head.title: The Export-Import Bank: Who Is Helping Whom?

hedline.hl1: The Export-Import Bank: Who Is Helping Whom?

abstract.p: California Space Authority chief executive Robert M Davis letter on September 1 article on credit aid given by Export-Import Bank of US holds satellite buyer's wealth and manufacturer's politics are irrelevant

block.p: The article began with an example of a loan guarantee provided by the bank for the sale of a satellite manufactured in the United States to an international telecommunications company. It also discussed the satellite buyer's wealth and the manufacturer's politics, neither of which I believe to be relevant.

The article began with an example of a loan guarantee provided by the bank for the sale of a satellite manufactured in the United States to an international telecommunications company. It also discussed the satellite buyer's wealth and the manufacturer's politics, neither of which I believe to be relevant.

What is relevant is that an international telecommunications company needed to buy a satellite. That company had a choice: it could buy the satellite from an American manufacturer or from a European one.

Following a basic principle of business, the telecommunications company compared prices, including the cost of financing. At a purchase price of $150 million to $200 million, a small difference in an interest rate can make or break a deal.
In this case, the company chose an American manufacturer in part because the Export-Import Bank provided a loan guarantee that allowed the company to get a lower interest rate for the loan.

It is well known that European satellite manufacturers offer government-provided financing options to their customers. To compete effectively with these European rivals, the nation's satellite manufacturing industry must have available government financing options.

Loan guarantees are not corporate welfare. As the article states, the default rate on these loans is extremely small -- about 2 percent. Instead, the guarantees are a small and necessary national investment in the nation's satellite manufacturing industry.

The global satellite industry is facing a steep decline in market demand due to a downturn in the telecommunications industry. It is projected that only two or three of the world's five commercial satellite manufacturers will survive current market conditions. Continued assistance from the Export-Import Bank is required to ensure that at least one of the survivors will remain in the United States.
ROBERT M. DAVIS Santa Maria, Calif., Sept. 9
The writer is president and chief executive of the California Space Authority, a group that promotes space projects in the state.
